Comments: This solution presents a comprehensive model for evaluating the feasibility of high-speed rail (HSR) systems, considering ridership, environmental impact, and costs. It uses a detailed ridership model that incorporates commuter behavior, travel time, and cost differences. The cost model includes locomotive and infrastructure costs, with separate calculations for track and station expenses. The solution also analyzes the environmental benefits in terms of reduced diesel fuel consumption. The response is well-organized, clearly written, and provides a thorough analysis.

Q1.Definition: Determine ridership numbers over the next 20 years to predict the demand for HSTs.
Assumption: Individuals would choose the most cost-effective method of transportation, regardless of what other people do.
Tracks are laid in the shortest distance between the stations and that the cost of track is $9 million per km.
All rail systems would run on electric power, similar to Amtrak's Acela Express.
The weight of a passenger is insignificant compared to the overall weight of a train.
All passenger cars and train stations cost the same amount to build.
Trains are filled to maximum capacity.
Percent growth per state is constant.
Model: Number of commuters in a city: c \* |A|, where c is the proportion of long-distance commuters and |A| is the city population.
City population growth: |A(t)| \= |A|0(1 \+ r)^t, where r is the growth rate and t is time in decades.
Proportion of city commuters travelling a specific path: L(A, B, t) \= c \* |A(t)| \* (|B(t)| / sum(|J(t)|)), where L(A, B, t) is the number of commuters from city A to city B at time t.
Benefit of HST commuting: Q(A, B) \= k \* Δt(A, B) \+ Δc(A, B), where Δt is time saved, Δc is money saved, and k is a conversion factor.
Actual proportion of HST commuters: P(Q) \= 1 / (1 \+ e^((10-Q)/2.5))
Ridership along a specific path: R(A, B, t) \= L(A, B, t) \* P(Q(A, B))
Total ridership: R(t) \= sum(R(A, B, t)) over all city pairs (A, B).
Q1.Results: Ridership projections for each region over 20 years (presented in a graph).
Q1.Sensitivity Analysis: Not explicitly mentioned in the ridership section, but the model incorporates various factors and parameters.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Detailed model considering various factors influencing ridership.
Strength: Uses a logical approach to calculate the proportion of commuters choosing HST.
Weakness: Relies on several assumptions, including constant commuter proportion and uniform city 'pull'.
Weakness: Assumes all commuters purchase a monthly pass.

Q2.Definition: Determine the financial costs of HSTs, including construction, maintenance, and environmental costs.
Model: Locomotive costs: Includes construction and maintenance costs. Construction cost based on TGV Reseau cost per seat. Maintenance cost based on repair frequency and cost per repair.
Infrastructure costs: Includes track costs and station costs.
Track costs: Based on distance and a cost of $5.59 million/km.
Station costs: Based on the number of stations and a cost of $366,772 per station.
Total costs: Sum of locomotive and infrastructure costs.
Q2.Results: Total cost (locomotive and infrastructural) per region over time (presented in a graph).
Q2.Sensitivity Analysis: Not explicitly performed for the cost models.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Comprehensive cost model considering various factors.
Strength: Uses real-world data for cost estimations.
Weakness: Relies on several assumptions, including constant track costs and uniform station costs.
Weakness: Assumes all trains are diesel powered.

Q3.Definition: Prioritize the geographic regions based on the difference between benefit and cost.
Model: Environmental benefit: Calculates the amount of diesel fuel saved per person per year by switching from driving to riding HST.
Cost-benefit analysis: Compares the total cost (initial and operating) with the total revenue (ticket sales and oil savings).
Prioritization: Regions are ranked based on net profit (or loss) over 20 years.
Results: On average, 107 gallons of foreign diesel were saved per person per year.
None of the regions made an estimated net profit.
Ranking of regions from least to greatest net loss: Southeast, Florida, Pacific Northwest, Keystone, California, South Central, Chicago Hub Network, Empire, Northern New England, and Gulf Coast.
Q3.Sensitivity Analysis: Not explicitly performed for the cost-benefit analysis.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Considers both financial and environmental benefits.
Strength: Provides a clear ranking based on cost-benefit analysis.
Weakness: Relies on assumptions about fuel savings and oil prices.
Weakness: Does not consider potential economic benefits beyond ticket sales and oil savings.
